results.title: Basketball diaries
results.creator_credit: Island Pictures, Liz Heller and Scott Kalvert
results.brief_description: ‘The Basketball Diaries’ is a horrowing growing-up story based on the true-life exploits of poet and musician Jim Carroll. Jim begins as a high-school basketball star at a Catholic high school where he experiments with drugs and is physically abused by his teachers. When his best friend dies of leukemia, Jim’s life suddenly becomes much more than adolescent angst, with him making the dark descent into the hell of heroin addiction and hustling. Jim’s poetry is the only thing he has left when he is found, literally on the street, by a tough ex-junkie, who undertakes his rehabilitation. Cast include: Leonardo Di Caprio, Bruno Kirby, Juliette Lewis and Ernie Hudson.

results.title: Basket case
results.creator_credit: Analysis Films, Edgar Levins and Frank Henenlotter
results.brief_description: Hilarious, cult, low-budget, highly eccentric slasher horror flick from Frank Henenlotter is about two Siamese twins, reluctantly separated in adolescence by merciless doctors. Seeking revenge, the two (one a full bodied man, and the other a head in a basket) set up in a seedy New York hotel, where they encounter an array of fringe dwellers. Minimal and basic special effects do not detract from the gruesome fun of seeing a mutant, enraged head on the rampage. Followed by two sequels in the 1990s.

results.title: Basic instinct (E)
results.creator_credit: Carolco Pictures, Studio Canal+, Alan Marshall and Paul Verhoeven
results.brief_description: Destined to become a modern classic, Paul Verhoeven’s effort has brought new definition and brilliance to the “femme fatale” of the film noir genre. It is all here, temptation, sex and murder, and all in the guise of a voluptuous beautiful woman. Michael Douglas plays an ex-undercover cop, burnt out and recovering from drug and alcohol addiction when he becomes involved with the investigation of a brutal murder. The prime suspect is a very rich, very beautiful young woman (Sharon Stone) who’s calm and collected exterior belies a predatory and hedonistic soul. Shocking, controversial and explicit, this is not a film for the squeamish. Co-starring George Dzundza.

results.title: Barton Fink
results.creator_credit: Circle Films, Ethan Coen and Joel Coen
results.brief_description: New York City, 1941. Barton Fink is a successful Hollywood writer who has come to the land of the rich and famous to make it big in the movies. However, now that Hollywood has embraced him, he finds himself suffering from a severe case of writer’s block, has a movie mogul with a passion for wrestling breathing down his neck, and an insane insurance salesman wanting to separate his head from his neck. An enormously amusing crackpot view of the underside of the Hollywood dream and a wonderful, if slightly bizarre, investigation of the creative mind in turmoil. Cast includes John Turturro, John Goodman, Judy Davis, Michael Lerner and John Mahoney.

results.title: Barry Lyndon
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Stanley Kubrick and Ken Adam
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by William Makepeace Thackeray, Kubrick’s film portrays the rise and fall, in eighteenth century Ireland and England, of Barry Lyndon - an adventurer-gambler, a cad and a romantic idealist. The film follows Lyndon from his humble Irish heritage, through his ambitious and manipulative exploits to gain favour and power in the high echelons of society and then to his eventual rejection by, and resulting demise at the hands of the overtly hierarchical society he idealised. Kubrick departs from Thackeray’s picaresque novel in both scope and tone, replacing the first person narration of the novel with that of the third person, adding to a sense of detachment and abstraction. Meticulously designed and crafted with period detail and lit entirely by natural light in both interior and exterior settings, this film evokes a subtle yet striking sense and critique of the cultural rituals and trappings that pervaded eighteenth century life and its impact on human identity and values. (Awards: Best Art Direction/Set Decoration, Best Cinematography, Best Costume Design, and Best Adaptation. British Academy Awards for Best Director and Best Cinematography)

results.title: Barefoot in the park
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Hal B Wallis and Gene Saks
results.brief_description: Jane Fonda and Robert Redford star in this Neil Simon comedy about a newly married couple. Corey and Paul Bratter begin their marriage in a tiny one-roomed apartment up six flight of stairs with the weirdest neighbours on Tenth Street. Corey is vivacious, fun-loving and impetuous, while Paul is a rising and very serious young Attorney. Joy turns to anguish, but they kiss and make up in the end. Fonda and Redford are delightful, while Charles Boyer as the aging Romeo who lives in the attic, and Mildred Natwick as Corey’s meek and mild mother are excellent. The script has the wit of Simon’s New York perspective.

results.title: Barcelona [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: New Visions Pictures and Whit Stillman
results.brief_description: An off-beat and ironic talk-fest from director Whit Stillman, this is a dry, insightful comedy about two American cousins in post-Franco Spain. Ted Boynton, an overly serious salesman, who is in the midst of recovering from a broken relationship and questioning his vocation originally inspired by an Arthur Miller play, is suddenly faced with the arrival of his arrogant navy cousin Fred. What ensues is a series of intensive bar crawls where the cousins encounter a group of women from the Trade Centre, one of whom Ted promptly falls in love with. A study of the life and attitudes of two Americans abroad underlies this comic romantic tale through which the film takes on a more serious satirical tone. As the film progresses, the ineptitude of Ted and Fred to integrate with the values of the culture they inhabit is only exceeded by the anti-American sentiment in Spain which the characters do not remain untouched by, but are slow to recognise. This film will no doubt appeal to fans of Whit Stillman’s characteristic distanced play between amusement and substantial critique.

results.title: Barbie in the nutcracker
results.creator_credit: Mattel, Mainframe Entertainment, Jesyca C Durchin, Jennifer Twiner McCarron and Owen Hurley
results.brief_description: Superb computer animation brings Barbie to life in this modernized adaptation of E.T.A. Hoffmann’s classic story, ‘The Nutcracker’. Story heroine Clara receives a wooden Nutcracker as a gift from an aunt. As she sleeps the Nutcracker comes to life to save her from the evil Mouse King, who has invaded Clara’s house, unfortunately. Clara wakes and is shrunk by the Mouse King. The only person who can break the Mouse King’s spell and restore Clara to her original size is the Sugarplum Fairy, so Clara and the Nutcracker set off to find her. In her first full length movie, Barbie assumes the roles of Clara and the Sugarplum Fairy. Choreographed by Peter Martins and performed for animation by the New York City Ballet. Tchaikovsky’s musical score is performed by the London Symphony Orchestra. Features voices from Kelly Sheridan (Barbie/Clara), Kirby Morrow (Nutcracker/Prince Eric),Tim Curry (Mouse King), Peter Kelamis (Pimm), Christopher Gaze (Major Mint), Ian James Corlett (Captain Candy), French Tickner (Grandfather Drosselmayer) and Kathleen Barr (Aunt Drosselmayer).

results.title: Barbarella [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Marianne Productions, De Laurentiis Entertainment Group, Dino De Laurentiis and Roger Vadim
results.brief_description: This cult film by New Wave director Roger Vadim begins with a flawlessly executed zero gravity strip-tease by the film’s feisty 41st century space adventurer, Barbarella (Jane Fonda). The adventure begins when the president of Earth contacts Barbarella for her help in locating Durand Durand (Milo O’Shea), a young scientist who has vanished with a deadly positronic ray that contains the power to “shatter the loving union of the universe”. Her mission takes an unexpected twist after her fur-lined vessel makes a forced landing on the icy planet Lythion after being rocked by a magnetic disturbance. Barbarella soon faces a number of challenging situations that result in many costume changes, and pleasurable encounters with the handsome men who assist her as she continues to track the elusive Durand Durand. With the help of the angel, Pygar (John Phillip Law), Barbarella must infiltrate the city of SoGo and battle the Black Guards and the Great Tyrant - a sadistic seductress who wants Barbarella for her own devious purposes - to recover the devastating weapon and restore peace and order to the galaxy. Based on the French science-fiction comic by Jean-Claude Forest, with dazzling and inventive costume design by Jacques Fonteray and Paco Rabanne.
